Early Access Review
								I started playing this game late in 2013.  I registered in the beginning of 2014, and my adventure started from there.  This game has been unique to me in so many aspects, I really don't have the room in a review to talk about them all.  The sandbox aspects, the fact it's an indie game by basically a one-man-team, or the fact it's the most expansive space-sim I've played to date, bringing back nostalgia of Freelancer.One thing that has kept me going is the continuous rise of the community.  Slowly, we had less than five active players for weeks on end.  Then a few dozen in the next months.  Eventually, the game expanded and more players joined, and I really felt the small part of the mysterious galaxy we were all in come alive.  Industry was a boon, mining operations became a thing, and eventually the galactic market was properly being utilized which was surprising to many of us so early on.I eventually had to take a break to focus on real life, but this game was always great about treating you right.  I could play for 15 minutes or 12 hours a day, didn't matter - I progressed.  I could skip weeks or months at a time, didn't matter, I could start off right where I left off.  It's always been a pleasure seeing the game constantly updated on a daily basis.  It's been even more of a pleasure having a dev who will directly communicate and give his time of day to the players.I was a skeptic at first, but soon came to truly believe in there being billions of solar systems to explore, everything procedurally generating to be a unique experience every time.  Eventually, players started exploring and graphing charts of planets and moons to settle on.  Then players started constructing gates, expanding the inner systems, and really bringing the heart of the game to life - the reconstruction of the empire of humanity.It's been over a year now, and myself and other older vets have watched this game bloom like a beautiful flower, and I'm proud to write such a positive review for it.  I could sit and try to come up with excuses all day long, but I honestly can't, this game has been going in the right direction nonstop, and has never ran out of *ahem* Steam.If you want to see what the game looked like a year ago - and my basic introduction to it, check out my youtube channel:  http://www.youtube.com/sinstrite  There are also new videos being uploaded right now, based on my attempt at a Let's Play of the game.  I don't think a Let's Play has been attempted with a game quite like this, so I find it interesting myself how tough it is to actually product the content.Here are some helpful links!http://www.thespacegame.com - play in the web browser for freehttp://forum.thespacegame.com/index.php - the official forumshttp://wiki.thespacegame.com/mediawiki/index.php/Main_Page - the official wikihttp://www.facebook.com/TheSpaceGame - the official facebook pagehttp://thespacegame.uservoice.com/forums/194252-general - vote for player ideasI really do advise the new player to visit the wiki.  Many veterans have put in a lot of work to build it from the ground up, and even as one of the oldest players I still find myself using it constantly.  Let it be your space-bible.Keep in mind that you purchased the game for $10.00 and paid another $10.00 for the three months of premium bundled with the purchase.  When you first start, do not use your premium right away, save it for when you will most be able to use it.Planetary Premium - $0.99 monthly - You get access to the six other planets to build settlements on.  As a free player you can only access Ceres for grain and Vulcan for Iron.  You will also be able to produce: titanium, carbon, aluminium, meat, fruit, vegetables.  This is very good for expanding your starbase later on which brings us to...Industry Premium - $0.99 monthly - Use this to expand your Apollo starbase to 100 rings (600 modules) and really pump out some products with your factories.  You can make a lot of progression this way as a new player, and I highly advise you to get all 100 rings going if you plan on building a colony later on.  This also allows you to use modules above class 5 such as the mining beam, ram scoop, salvage beam, etc.  This really is the best premium to purchase in my opinion.Combat Premium - $0.99 monthly - If you want to make some credits fighting in Janus A, you want to throw some huge guns on your ship.  With this premium, you can access all weaponry over class 5 which allows you to move to the highest rank, making around 60,000,000 each mission ;)For you want-to-be colony builders...  You need Stellar Credits.  Each premium gives you 100 stellar credits a month, so if you have all three premiums going, you get 300 SC a month.  A colony costs 80 a month to upkeep, so you can have three colonies just for having the three premiums.OSB - Starbases that can be attached to your colony in high orbit.  They costs SC if they are not attached, but are free if they are.Other acronyms:MB / ML - Mining Beam, Mining LevelRS - Ram ScoopTS - Trading SkillSB - StarbaseHD - HyperdriveCL - ClassMD - ModuleSY - ShipyardGH - Gas harvestingHydro - Hydrogen (used to power ships when hyperjumping)MP - Mechanical PartsEL - ElectronicsGR / Graph - Graphene (made from carbon)SC, SCC, SCoil - Superconducting CoilsNio - Niobium (mined from Columbite)Aut - Autunite (gives uranium for contracts)SS - Space StationKS - KickstarterSteamie - What the players who came in through the Steam purchases are calledElders - Players that have been around for a year or longerVets - Players that have played months before the Steam releaseIf I think of more I will add them, and one more thing.../ignore PLAYERNAME is your best friend.

												Ascent is a fantastic concept, a PvE version of EVE Online without the real time skill training. It is still early access, but it is my opinion that the direction of the game is going in such a way that a negative review was needed as a warning for future purchasers. If there was a "neutral" button for the review I would have used it.User InterfaceThe game’s user interface is horrid.  You will notice it the minute you hit the startup screen.  Instead of a login and character selection screen it has a button series that looks like a single player game, up to and including a “LOAD” button.  Fitting ship modules is a complex and clucky text selector box maneuver.CommunityThe community is friendly, and will answer basic questions in game chat. There is only one “global” game chat, and no in-game guilds or other such mmo “norms”. GraphicsThe game uses stock Unity graphics for the most part. The ships and starbases may have been a unity resource pack purchase. The game had a kickstarter specifically to add ship graphics, but everything else is very simplistic.  Planets are little more than a multicolored globe and your character avatar is a guy in a tee shirt and jeans. Still early access.Player CooperationThe game might as well be single player. Your “cooperation” with other players will be limited to buying stuff from them off a market board.  Even such grand ventures such as building a new jump gate basically boils down to hauling loads of minerals.  There is no “grouping” for combat, no sharing ownership or access to buildings, no real reason for other players to be in the game aside from a chat based social and game-economy aspect.Ship DesignEach ship “class” is just a different skin.  The only technical difference between the base ship “skins”  is that each class increase basically doubles the cargo space. There is a marginal difference in turning, but basically the only real game mechanic-based difference in the ships would be cargo space.  A higher level ship can equip higher level modules, such as a better mining laser.Grindy and RepetativeAscent is extremely grindy. You will buy and sell resources via NPC contracts, or buy and sell resources for other players, or mine.  Your ships cargo is the only limiter, when you purchase a new ship you gain more cargo space, thus the grind starts anew for the next ship.  You will also need to grind to purchase blueprints, planet plot deeds, and a hyperdrive.  ExplorationThis seems like a fun concept, and the developer brags about 300 billion star systems; however, you need cargo space to carry fuel for the hyperjump so you will need to grind a lot of money to purchase a decent sized ship and hyperdrive (ships on the NPC market do not come with them).  The ship’s hyperdrive allows you to explore and discover new star systems; however, they get more expensive the larger your ship is (almost always being the same price as the ship itself). For a game that brags about exploration, they sure do make it hard.Also, you get a star system named after you just for being the first person to jump to it. No real planet exploration is required.  Basically, you are getting credit for a "discovery" that was already made by some guy with a telescope years before.Pay To WinYou can skip the grind and buy a bowhead, one of the largest ships in the game. ComplexThe game has a steep learning curve. I did not mind this too much, but it is worth mentioning.  You will be doing a lot of wiki research and youtube video watching.

Early Access Review
								I started playing this game several days ago before the Steam release because I couldn't wait for the release (with over 40hrs of playtime) I'm glad I did as well. This game is amazing on so many levels. It's well worth the $20. There are some caveats however that are worth noting to those thinking about purchasing.The game purchase will get you most of the features in the game except for full colonies. To have full colonies you will need to have a premium account. For all three premium features it costs $3 a month. The point to the premium is to help support the cost of running the servers. Without premium you'll also only have access to one space station ring, with premium you get up to 100. When you purchase the game you will get a 3 month trial of the premium service so you can try out colony building if you so desire.Even with the above caveat this is still not a pay to win game. You don't need to have premium to have a full immersive experience of the game. Here's a list of the pro's/cons of the game:Overall rating 9/10+Huge universe with 270 billion star systems with only a handful having been discovered so far.+A very friendly and helpful community+Fast space travel (seriously fast autopiloting system & warp gates)+Resource harvesting including asteroid mining, gas harvesting by skimming gas giants, colonies that mine resources+Smooth stable game play client & server (In over 40hrs of playing I have had the client crash once and almost no lag or latency issues)+Developer that logs into the server and gets input from his players!+Good tutorial that isn't overbearing (think breadcrumbs)+Good selection of ships that aren't too difficult or time consuming to get.-Registration is a tad confusing for new players and is on the list to be reworked/fixed-Graphics are not the best compared to other games out there however with graphics at max it still looks amazing-Need premium to access colonies (as noted above)Some special notes:Mining: Mining is not the boring thing I've experienced in most space games where you just find the rocks and shoot them to harvest. In this game the different asteroids have different compositions yielding different minerals/metals. Also the asteroid fields move, so the rocks don't just float in space. You have to match speeds with them and carefully fire your mining laser. The idea is to heat up the rock to a certain temperature to yield the materials. Too cold and it doesn't work, too hot and the rock explodes yielding you nothing. So, you have to pay attention to your mining beam and shut it off at the right time. Also, the range of each class of beam is different, at first you have to get within 1,000 meters to mine an asteroid.Trading: The game has a very well thought out trade infrastructure and system. Each of the core systems has a NPC Space Station that has a local market where you can sell goods & materials. Each station also specializes in producing one material for sale. Each core station also has a contract board where npc's offer contracts for needed items, passenger ferrying, blueprints for sale (for colonies & player stations), specialized colony supplies/materials, package deliveries etc. The contract board changes every hour, :15 after and :45 after the hour. The Galactic Market (or player market) is where players can offer goods for sale across the whole galaxy that can be searched from anywhere then when bought players have to travel to the selling location to pick up the goods. Also player colonies have stock markets where player harvested goods are bought and sold. With a little bit of time and help from the players you can make a lot of money trading on player stock markets or selling mined goods to colonies.Warp gates: outside the core 8 systems traveling requires a hyperdrive that burns hydrogen. So if you want to explore you will need those things and have some good skill in gas giant skimming. Also over the last several months several of the colonies just outside of the core 8 have developed into core systems and have built their own warp gates to the core systems. There are several gates being built now (requiring huge amounts of resources) these could be opportunites for traders and miners alike providing the resources for such gates. Also if one were to invest enough time and resources into a new system they could build their own gates to and from the core systems making player trading more viable and cost efficient.

								My updated video review:


YouTube™ Video: Ascent: The Space Game: Review 

			Views: 3,742		

			Today I review Ascent: The Space Game. I try to give an objective view on the game, and discuss whether it could be worth your money or not.		

------------------------------------My older text review:Wow...where do I start?Absolutely amazing game. The game is very immersive. Asteroids orbit around planets, you can land on planets to build things there, the crafting system is very complex and interesting, and you can even build your own space station which you can expand with many different kind of modules.Pros:- Very immersive environments. The space art is very nice and the planets look cool. Asteroid fields feel 'alive' with a lot of movement.- Great mining system. Mining is terribly boring in EVE, X, Elite Dangerous and Starpoint Gemini. However, here the mining is spiced up due to two facts:1) the asteroids have their own speed and your mining beam only has a 1km range, so you need to keep up with it (or fly very close to it)2) The amount you mine is dependent on the temperature of your mining beam. Beam too little and your yield is bad. Beam too much and you get nothing at all!- 250 billion systems to explore, that get named after you if you find them first! These systems can contain planets, which you can do geological research on to find out what it offers in terms of minerals etc. Other people (and you) can then colonize these planets, building factories etc. on them to profit from this planet.- Player-made economy! Everything except for the most basic resources are farmed/mined/made by the players to sell on the market!- You have to work for your things, and feel accomplished after you get a new ship or some other nice thing. Some people might mistake this for grindyness, which I wouldn't agree with (this comes from a person that absolutely despises 'daily quests' etc.).Cons:- some people dislike the graphics. I must say, when you're playing it, I think it looks gorgeous. Yes, the shipmodels are undetailed, but somehow they still look nice when you play it. But then again, I never cared for graphics that much (love Dwarf Fortress for example), so I might not be the right person to ask- complicated at times. If you want to play this game, you'll have to be ok with reading up on the wiki. While features are being added, things like ejecting cargo is done at the moment through a command console. I expect buttons for this will be made at some point, but they're not implemented yet (you can program in keybinds to eject cargo etc. though, but for this you need to read up).All in all, I'm in love. I would summarize it as a PvE version of EVE online. It's very much focussed on industry etc. instead of PVP/ganking.

Product received for free
Ascent is a deep colonization sandbox economic sim with unparalleled tech & scientific design. It's a combo of running the stock market, while setting up a space station for your own business in the stars. You mine, research, build, & generally act like a galactic Marco Polo, with as much or as little emphasis on either as you choose. You also take roles that resemble a tech tycoon like Steve Jobs, or an Admiral like Chester Nimitz of the US Navy. It also features political roleplay. The game is PVE focused. Combat is an option. You can choose to gain loot fighting pirates, as well as looking for wrecked ships by buying the location coordinates off the markets. You scan the wreckage & receive blueprints to design your own ship parts. You may choose to build a smuggling operation, by contacting npc’s on starbases & asking them to buy contraband. Once you’ve set up your contacts, you call them when ready to deliver, & bribe or avoid the guards to make the deliveries. &, best of all to me, you explore uncharted stars & they are named after you on the map. Gameplay:In Ascent, you have a persistent universe that provides a validity to your actions, a sense of player agency, because what you do matters. If you terraform a planet, other players can colonize on your planet also. You’ve created a new world with a breathable environment.To move around in the universe, you use the autopilot to take jump gates from planet to planet (or moon.) Or, you can use hydrogen & hyperdrives for FTL jumps. It has a few bugs. Nothing that affects enjoyment of the game, but IMHO, it probably was rushed out of EA a little fast (unlike some who flounder there forever.) Usually restarting the game clears any bug. They are regularly introducing new features, & working out the bugs. But, there's lots of info in the community wiki & on Waervyn’s World YouTube.Narrative:The game is built upon the premise of a world that has fallen into chaos. Your mission is to reorganize the world by setting up bases of operations in the inner 9 systems, then push outward to explore the stars beyond. The game has incredibly good voice acting & numerous missions that guide you through the story.The actual flight tutorial doesn’t seem very good, only causing stress to the new player, leaving you confused as to the focus of the game. Just say no to that, open the wiki, & jump right in with the WASD interface. The early Susan Steele Missions function as a de facto tutorial. After you do the few Steele missions, you then have a while to explore & expand before the later missions pop up. A simple & clear guide to the early game missions is Learning to Ascend’ by Max PowerMechanics:The mechanics let you feel like you are doing more than button pushing. Mining is like a dance with the asteroid. You pilot your ship to within close range of the rock, engage your gravity anchor to slow you down, & maintain a speed that matches the velocity of the asteroid while beaming it with your mining laser. You have to watch the color of the laser to know when you’ve heated it long enough to get the max elements from it. Too long will burn it up & you get nothing. If you are good at playing the market, you can search the stock market for incredible deals on most rare elements, available for you to just pick them up at the seller’s location. Graphics/ Sound:Ascent has simplistic graphics but is very deep technologically. It can be compared to games like Civ V & XCOM: Enemy Within, & fits somewhere in the middle as far as graphics design goes, with Civ V having the flat map, 2D perspective, with overlays for different actions, & popup messages; & XCOM having a 3d map system & voice-acting enrichment. You can really appreciate the fact that 1 man accomplished so much. The graphics are not of a quality you get from larger dev teams, with some flaws. But, they are totally immersive. As a matter of fact, the game ruined No Man’s Sky’s release for me. I got it a week before NMS finally launched, & now today stopped playing long enough to download NMS, only to find myself logging out again & firing back up Ascent. The maps are composed of a backbone of beautifully designed planetary art that you fly through in real-time within a celestial body’s range of view. These maps are lovely & each system has from 3-30 moons, gas giants, & rocky planets, each with their own design. For an idea of ship art, & to compare sizes, see my screenshots.The music is played at key moments, keeping distractions to gameplay to a minimum. The avatars are limited by 4, 2 each of male & female; with no choice for personalization. The ships can be painted, with rgb color sliders, so basically you have to mix the colors to get the color you want. It feeds the Science/Sci-fi feel to the game.MultiplayerIt is billed as an MMO simple enough for beginners to be able to get into. &, it does seem to be. The system seems less complex than other MMO's. I think that if there is a good starting place, this may be it. Ascent is the 1st MMO I’ve been able to successfully navigate. Being an older gamer, with a 20+ year gap in my gaming experience, I was thrilled to find an mmo that offers intelligently creative gameplay & still provides an ease of access for the casual gamer. There is a fanatic (& friendly) player base in Ascent. I’ve already clocked over 138 hours as of writing this review, & I’ve had the game about 9 days. Money (& Time) Matters:Ascent is underpriced at $20 bucks. I’ve enjoyed it more than Stellaris, because of the gameplay. The premium is unnecessary for those who just want to play normally. You would have to subscribe for a year for the cost to even approach the normal price of games like this. The 2 dlc ships are not only unnecessary to gameplay, since one is a class 1 support ship, & the other is a huge Bowhead too bulky for mining. Rather, they are novelties from the kickstarter reward tiers sold to finance the dev team, keeping the price of the game so cheap for others not interested in novelties. The best ship I’ve found so far for mining is the Mammoth class 10, because of its cargo capacity & maneuverability. I do love flying the different ships.You are sure to find many hours of your life lost to this game. It comes bundled with 3 free months of the premium access, which is not auto activated when you begin playing. I waited to activate my premium access until I had over 90 hours in the game. I could have waited longer, but I was limited to settlements on only two of the inner 9 planets, & only one ring on my inner starbase, &, I couldn't equip a hyperdrive above class 5 on a ship. (Same goes for ship combat weapons.) Trading cards for collecting art; as well as a nice artbook & music dlc package would be nice for those of us who like to see the creative process behind the game.Pros: *Space flight is all very realistic *Experience of a space traveler/ merchant miner*Results are skill-based, rather than luck or an old RNG*Pure Sic-fi …game backed by real Science*Provides a command line computer for conducting research & geological surveys Cons: *Preset instructions flash for only a second. Change that in options before you start*While in Shipyard, offers flash too fast for choosing, needs to be changed *Small bugs can be corrected by exiting game & reloading (works fast)*Needs an in-game logbook & a Transaction/Travel Record* A stock ticker on the hud would be a nice additionSometimes artistry is lost for the sake of making money. But, Fluffy Kitten Studios have created a work of heart, which is apparent in their pricing model as well as their gameplay.  I highly recommend Ascent for those of us for whom the world is not enough. One world, that is. In Ascent, many worlds will open up before you; worlds of celestial bodies, worlds of gameplay, & worlds of scientific exploration.

								For such a small development team with limited funds and an Early Access state, the game is amazingly stable. Granted I've played for about 4 hours as of writing this, but I have the graphics maxed out and have not experienced a single crash. 												After over 5000 hours playing, here is my review. I am in no way associated with the company that provides Ascent. I am just a long time player.What Ascent Is and Is NotAscent came on line mid 2013. Since then, there has been many changes and additions. With all those changes, there are still some things at the core of the game that can be highlighted.Ascent is:A sandbox. Similar to Lego, it gives the player pieces to create what each person imagines within the boundaries of the game environment. We are given set pieces and are allowed to put them together as we want. A MMO (Massively Multiplayer Online) game. It allows players to interact, chat, trade, and cooperate in game play and on large projects such as jump gate building and terraforming worlds. At the core of the game is a place to cooperate. An environment with 270,000,000,000 stars, each explorable with an average of 10 planets/moons in each star system. It is an entire galaxy waiting to be discovered. Each system is procedurally created from random seeds. This means that each system can have a wide variety of differing features, planets, and resources from a base standard set of resources which are available in game. Some are quite common, while a few are quite rare, yet all have been found and can be available to any player within the game. A game with a very basic storyline. We are not forced within a story that limits the players to a defined outcome or role. We are free to create our own story and empire. The dynamics are very easy to work with and after a short time, each player soon becomes a tycoon or master of their realm. There is so much room to play, that one can create an empire and never bump into another player, or create their empire on well established systems and join in on the projects going on within the game. One can switch back and forth between the two easily if mood calls for a day alone, or a day of play and interactions with the community. A place for traders. Trade is another core part of the game. Players can trade with NPC Space Stations in the Inner9 systems, or player Stock Markets in the outer systems. Mining asteroids is also a way to get free resources and sell to players or SS Local Markets for high profit trading. A Relaxed Community. Because we are given tools of cooperation, not destruction, we are able to assist each other and coordinate our efforts for the good of humanity, not the destruction of it. We get to know each other and enjoy catching up and joking. While we take the game seriously, we can relax and enjoy interacting and relating to each other. The game has a light layer of politics with a few elected positions, so good relations are also a tool within game to further one’s political career. The game waits for the player and is designed for someone to either play heavily, or a few hours a week, if they choose. The few quests in game are more for a tutorial than for locked in play. One can start and stop them at any time and place. Once achieved, the quests are done and allows for a return to relaxed free play. One can even drop into and out of the quests and the storyline waits for the player to want to go to the next step in the quest. The community also puts a lot of time and effort into creating game support. The game wiki pages are supplied and run by the players along with multiple other support tools. While play style can be relaxed, one can do some serious number crunching and documenting. Again, the player gets to choose which way they want to play.A light PvE(Player versus Environment) game. There are Non Player Character (NPC) pirates that are limited to selected areas. These are the only things players can shoot and attack. They are only in designated areas, so one has to seek them out. This allows to player co choose if they want to fight, or just build your empire. It allows for the relaxed game play. Pirates can be engaged, or ignored. A player can choose to take out some pirates one day and ignore them the next. Not a finished game. The game is well developed, but not completed. With one developer and many pieces available, like Legos, it can be a never ending play, or one you build a few things, then grow tired. New pieces are added slowly at times and quickly other times. The simple things come fast, but the more complex parts of the game take much more development and come slower. Each piece gives multiple ways of using it, so one piece can just add a little, or change the entire game dynamic. We often do not know until exploring it for a while to see how it effects things. Again, part of the open play that some like, while others do not. Serious bugs are addressed and dealt with, but a few additions are still in process of completion and have small issues that are on the list to be fixed. These issues are not game breaking, but one does need to be patient as they are slowly woven into completed game design. While this can be frustrating to some, remembering that there are some interconnectivity of other features that are coming may be why it is left as is for the present. One developer has to choose what is critical to put time into. Sometimes that time is just running the business and design has to be put on the back burner for a bit. Looking back over the past 4 years, the speed of new game development and additions are quite impressive for one person to have achieved. There is plenty of content for the cost of the game. Not for everyone. Sandbox games are not for everyone. Some like the tight quests and goals set by a designer. Many enjoy the player to player conflicts. Others enjoy a harsh game environment they must struggle against. Ascent has none of these elements. Those seeking these things will not connect easily.Not a place for PvP (Player versus Player). It is a place that you can not loose what you have. No one can destroy something you have worked to build or create. The core of the game is construction, not destruction. One player can not negatively affect another player’s game in a major way. No one can own systems, planets, or asteroid fields. They are all open to everyone. While you can not be locked out of anything, you can also not lock out anyone else from anything except your own colonies and starbases. You control those areas and share the rest of the areas of play. If your goal is to cause grief to others, you will find you have little tools to do that. Ascent is not a place to go after others.No where close to finding Earth. The ultimate goal is to find our way back to Earth. There is so much room and game play left before we can get back to Earth. We are not even sure what is between us and Earth. We suspect some alien influence, but only one encounter of extraterrestrials while progressing through the Neptune Project quest has been revealed. Out fears are there is a large alien force that we much face as we get closer to Earth, but this is all speculation.Well worth the price. Along with the purchase of the game, the player gets 3 months of premium subscription. This is more than enough time to delve into and build a massive empire. If the player enjoys the community and game play, it is only $3 a month for premium access after the first 3 months. Ready for you. The game and welcoming community is always ready for many more new Pilot Citizens (PC). We need those who have the neural pathways (imaginary thing needed in game to use warp and hyperjump drives) which allow their imaginations to determine their game-play. Are you tired of the constant drama and conflict? Are you ready for a totally different way to play a MMO? Are you ready to join us as we work together continuing to expand humanity’s reach into the galaxy on our way home? If you have read this far, we think you may just be one of the ones we are looking for.

								Game is Good for its current early access state. It combines an open universe, resource manangement, exploration, and a little combat. The free content in the game is limited though.    The universe is a PVE environment so there is no worry about end gamers getting board and one shotting the little newbe's, like happons in EVE online a good deal. The non-hostile world is very relaxing, you travel, mine astroids, manage your holdings, make money, spend more money, make upgrades with little to stress you out. You can do anything in game you want, although you really can't get away from mining, at least not until later in the game when you own a lot of production, and even then the late game is when mining is most productive. Making money can be be easy most of the time, you can take contracts to buy and sell goods, deliver people to other places, but mining tends to best for time verses money.  There are 2 main astroid belts in the core systems, the roid respawn rate is good but there is usually an over abundence of people in the belts competing for the good ones.  Its best to get out of the core systems to make mining less crowded, though early game your mining with suck too much to make the long hauls worth while. You will be able to buy plots of land on the core planets and set up resource gathering, each core planet supports a different resource type. These plots take a lot of time, money, resources, and planning to get set up. Its best to reseach this aspect of the game before blindly dropping buildings down. Same applys to your first space station, early game the only thing your spacestation dose i suck you dry of money and materials. One day mine will make things but for now i have spent a weekend marathon gathering what i need to make the 6 buildings its supports, it will likly be another week or so before it produces anything. The combat is clunky early game, later when you have access to turrets and broadsides it might be better but i am not there yet. There is only 1 location at this time where you can fight, and have to start missions to get the enemys to spawn. There are no hostile forces anywhere except that one system, and you cannot run into them accidentally. So thats nice in many ways, though i would not mind a couple of pirate systems where there is more combat to be had. The game is a grind, its take a good deal of time and resources to get anything done, but your ability to procure stuff tends to scale with you as you progress in the game. For example early game the idea of mining 1000 ore for a project is brutal but later in the game you can mine that and more off 1 astroid. The community does not seem overly large but is generally helpful. At this time there tends to be a good amount of "help the new guys" mentalitly out there, it's not uncommon for someone to sell you their ship cheaply when they get a new one. The market however is driven by the players and in the week i have been playing has been driving to rather insane levels. In the first few days of the game for me one of the ships i wanted was running around 100k, a good grind for my skill level and equipment. Now after only a week the average price for the same ship is hovering around 1mil. The ship is not worth half that but thats the nature of these games.  You have to be patient when buying and wait for good deals or just suck it up and pay ripeoff prices. Late game vehicles are a different story, the price tag can hit the billions mark but for the time and resources thay take its understandable.  You must watch ship your buying, there are real A-holes out there who can ripe you off, a ship must have every peice of equipment on it to leave space dock, (with the exception of weapons and hyperdrives). There are people out there who will look at the average price of the ships of that type and put one up for sale very cheaply, many people seeing the low cost buy it up quickly thinking they got a good deal. When you click on a ship in the galactic market watch out for a red warning at the bottom of the ship data, the warning will tell you and ship cannot fly becuase its missing a piece or peices of equipment. If it something like a mining laser or armor its no big deal and you can take those off your current ship. if the item is a ship teir specific item like a reactor the ship is junk. Most of the ships systems have to match the level of that ship, so you cannot take stuff form a smaller ship to put on it. At this time you cannot sell ships to the AI only to other players, so once you upgrade you leave your old ship where ever you picked up the new one at. There is not a way to bring all your ships to one location so a common tactic, once you have a space station running, is to part at your station, build a shuttle and take the shuttle to pick up your new baby.  There are a number of things that annoy new players, the tutorials can be a little vague and do not explain what to do clearly much of the time, those of us to game a lot get through them fine but many flood chat with the same questions over and over. You are frequently told to go to the Wiki or check online, i find both those lacking. Much of the time you will not find the information you need online or on the wiki.....(least not on google seachs anyway)(anyone know of a real seach engine so i can stop the google uselessness). The game is only arond $20, it also offers a subscription. If your going to play this game seriously your going to need to pay.  For Non-prem players you can own anyship you can buy or build, but are limited to Class 5 equipment (Equipment goes to class 12 i think). You can buy and use higher class equipment but it will only function as class 5. Mining at class 5 is good for early to mid game but for end game needs will not cut it. Your starbase is limited to 6 buildings without premium, once again good enough for early game but not acceptable for late game unless you like projects taking several real world months to complete. You cannot make colonies in the outer systems unless you have premium. So there is a lot of pay to get anywhere in this game.  At this time there are no micro transactions though, you can't buy ships, resourced and such with real money, all has to be aquired in-game with in-game money. I guess this game is larger an MMO of sorts. I like the game but have already started making spreadsheet and such to manage my small and pathentic empire, so yes the game is already becoming work. I have not decided if i want to pay the subscription or not and thus contiune playing. But at the point i am at in game the lack of premuim is not hurting me yet, one more ship upgrade and i will have to make the money decision though.

								Firstly, ignore the hours on record; I have invested a lot more hours in this than is shown here, however a lot of other players in the community has spent countless more than me :)Ascent is a genuine space-based sandbox where depth triumphs over flashy graphics and CGI and actually provides you with a genuine sanbox experience where you have the freedom to go anywhere and do whatever you want. Outside of the initial tutorial (Which covers all the basics of the game), nothing is necessary to complete to progress in the game how you want (Even the story missions are optional). Do you want to make your fortune by travelling to distance systems and mining rich resources? Or, would you rather spend time jumping to systems 100's of light years out from the inner 9 systems and discovering what new worlds the procedural generated engine generates (Which can be marvels to behold, including purple methane oceans)? Or, take on the pirates of the universe and help clean-up the troubles in Janus-A on behalf of the UAE? Or, buy up all the resources available and become an industrial manufacturing mogul? Or, colonise remote systems and begin harvesting raw materials to sell back to other players?On top of the sandbox approach to this game, the other main strength is how the player base has shaped and expanded on the game. Not only is the economy in the game driven by the players (Pro tip: sell all mined Niobium and Tin to players and not NPC's), the players are also deriving their own content and expanding the known galaxy beyond the inner 9 star systems. From building remote colonies and star bases through to jump-gates to remote systems to connect remote colonies to the inner 9 without the need to use a hyperdrive, the player base and its strength will be what keeps the content generation going for a long time to come. Also, there is a democracy at play where players have the ability to vote for their president, as well as senators of star systems, governors of planets and even mayors of colonies. Lastly, a lot of the content in the game doesn't require you to be online to achieve. For example, colony builds will occur within a period of 24 hours (Usually), which happens even if you are offline. This also applies to any manufacturing or production you currently have at your colonies or star bases. This means that if you ever take a break for a couple of days, or have limited time to play, everything you have will keep manufacturing/producing without you.Ascent already has a lot of content to keep casual and hardcore players alike interested for a long time and with the up-and-coming features (Such as PvP and larger ships) it will only get bigger and better over time. Well worth the small monthly fee + initial purchase price.

								October 16 2016:So the game has been fully released, there's been constant updates, new ships added, Terraforming has now been added, combat reworks among other things.   I still definitely recommend this game, yes it still does have a premium membership, but it's approximately $ a month for being able to use larger than class 5 mining beams, etc etc.  you can still play the game without the premium.  October 26 2015:===================================================================In regards to the Pay-to-win comments such as:==================================================================="Pay To WinThe kickstarter crowd got a free ship called a “bowhead”. Biggest and best ship in the game, nothing even comes close. The kickstarter players that have a bowhead basically played the game in EZ mode. They didn’t have to worry about cargo spaces on starter ships, the skipped it. This provided the kickstarter crowd with a massive, and in my opinion, game-breaking advantage.One of the kickstarter “options” also provided a planet terraformer, once again something that only the kickstarter crowd got.Those who paid the developer got a massive game advantage. This is a gamebreaking advantage due to the fact that a ship's cargo space determines how much money can be made ... and how much fuel the ship can carry to jump to and explore other systems."===================================================================My Response:===================================================================For starters when the kickstarter crowd got their bowheads, there still weren't Hyperdrives for it (had to be researched up to get towards them), there weren't massive colonies supplying every resource you could possibly think of, so asteroids had to be mined for all the resources that were needed for mass colony production.   In regards to the terraforming devices, they are in no way pay to win, as anyone can use those planets for their own colonies.  Terraforming devices gave us ALL the ability to have colonies without the need of environmental domes all over.===================================================================--New Thoughts--===================================================================I've got almost 1200 hours into this game, and I feel that that numbers only going to go higher and higher.  I have over 300 titles on steam, and this is the first game I've actually broken 1000 hours on.  There have been many improvements to this game such as updated effects in colony construction that make it easier to track the buildings you are placing.  An updated chat system has been added that allow the creation of our own channels, as well as a help, a trade, and a global channel.  Smuggling has been implemented which can be quite fun, but is only meaningful for newer players at the moment.  Co-op combat and the combat rework will be coming soon.Economy Balance has been brought into the game through an elected President roll allowing the modification of what colonies will purchase minerals at, approving gates to the inner 9 systems etc. A few people have put negative reviews up here because of the nerf to carbon hauling.  We used to be able to print billions of credits for almost no effort hauling carbon to the inner systems.  Several people invested their colonies entirely into carbon, and because of the nerf to prices they rage quit, caused a lot of drama and put out some negative reviews.   They aren't wrong on all of their points, but they're coming from a perspective of upset and disheartenment.Still one of the best communities out of any online game.  Entire community spirit of the game is based on cooperation, so if that's what you're looking for, this is where it is. ===================================================================--Original Review--===================================================================This game is a lot of fun.The game is still in Alpha stage at the moment, and while there are a lot of needed QoL updates, the basic, and even a lot of the more advanced gameplay features are functioning as they should.This game is very different than most other MMOs.   The pace isn't fast, you don't rush for anything, you can try, but it's still going to take time to learn the game, to progress through research, and to learn more as you go.   A little bit complicated to figure out at first, but once you do figure it out it's easy to learn more.The community in this game is extremely helpful, and mature.  The developer is Dedicated, and has a good idea where he's going with the game.    after 500 hours in I'm still enjoying nearly everything to the game.If you would like a headstart I highly recommend watching some of the tutorials made by Waervyn.  They are highly understandable and explain things in much greater detail.https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLa53kfJdPTHCnVW7jAsLARIF1mVWwWxsxMining is a lot of fun, there's no AFKing to it, and there's no scooping stupid rocks each time.Trading is very profitable and fun once you've got the cargo space to make it worth your time.Combat is not quite done as of yet, but is the next priority on the developer's plan.  He has huge visions for where he wants to take this game, and it's going to be awesome to see what he does with combat.Exploration is incredibly fun.  From Extrememly rare Neutron stars to Blackholes to regular K type stars you can find it all.  Earth Like planets are rumored to exist but are insanely rare, the nebulae in systems are quite beautiful, and the planet procedural generation is really something to look at. Colony management has received updates now that make it so much easier to start building your colonies YAY :).  The Dev is currently seeking a UI Programmer for , but the mechanics are very functional.  Very interesting game system different from pretty much any other game I can think of.  Sort of a Mix of Eve Online's Planetary Interaction, and X series Station building is the best way I can describe it.All in All worth every Penny.

At every station that I dock at, I go through the scrolling window and verify which contracts were fullfilled or just disappeared so I know exactly how much I need to get and deliver. For instance I know Elysium is the supplier of Titanium, and on my spreadsheet I see that I have a contract to deliver 56 units to Orion, three contracts with Mica (52, 44, and 34 units) and 34 units to Solaris. I have color coded the space stations so I know which warplines they are on. So I know I have to jump to Mica first, in order to continue down that warpline to Solaris.I have been able to upgrade ships quickly, so I am in a class 5 now and almost ready to buy a class 6. Unfortunately, I am not able to hire a pilot to run the old ships even though in the manage ship section there are text buttons for pilot and crew. You can sell your old ships on the galactic market, but you can not get back to your listed ship to change price or take it off the market. I have never received a notification of a listed ship being sold so there could be my class 1, 2, 3, and 4 ships still up for sale.A recent update gave us the option of turning off the white screen that shows during a warp. Unfortunately, we do not have any control over the rest of the psychedelic warp screens which show for way too long. There are no controls to set up a transit route or a trade route. If I had 58 iron, 42 grain, and 60 fruit in the hold and I am going from Andromeda to Plato to deliver the iron contract, then to Archon for the grain delivery, and finally to Solaris to deliver the fruit I have to manually select each warp gate and each station. So it would 12 warp segments to accomplish those deliveries. Each individual segment has to be done separately after sitting through another long viewing of the same psychedelic warp scene. Even cheap GPS units today allow you to do a trip plan with intermediate stops. Surely a civilization that has the technology to build warp gates and space stations could concieve of a better trip planner.At some warp gates a fuzzy red blob will come flying at you then execute a 90 degree turn and fly off into the heavens. Since the ship or shields have never been damaged, I have to assume that it is not someone attacking me. I have bought blueprints for each of the bays in the private space station and for a farm on the surface of Ceres. I have tried to deliver the farm robots and some material to the surface, but could not offload anything. 												Very fun concept, but crashes *CONSTANTLY*. Monthly subscription system is a major turnoff, too. Comes with a few months by default, which is nice, but there's a huge wall of grinding between you and getting to a lot of the features the game is advertised for. I have over a dozen hours and I'm still literally just grinding cash, trying to get a spaceship capable of going exploring out into the systems outside of the base 9. Most of this grinding is done by clicking autopilot buttons. Settlement and star base construction system has absurdly dumb crafting times (time per module is measured in a number of real time hours, often numbering above twenty - freaking - hours!). Number of colonies and star bases you can have is based on how much real money you spend per month - you can go and buy bigger subscriptions to get more planets. Your control over the planets you colonized is based on how many people have built colonies there and how willing you are to involve yourself in the politics process. As in, in-game elections and such. Which is an interesting concept, but I hesitate to see it in practice as it strikes me as a potentially nasty means of griefing. Combat is *extremely* clunky and awkward, and the radar system is in desperate need of a revamp. Indicators are small and difficult to make out unless you expand the radar, which makes it difficult to aim your frontal guns, which are fixed with your movement. There are broadside and 90 degree cone turrets, but those are totally automated and have no player input beyond placing them on your ship. As far as I can tell, there are no variety in weapons, and combat is restricted to one zone. All in all, this game strikes me as something I would expect to see out of an alpha. The graphics are rather weak compared to performance (I have a Radeon r9 380, 8 core AMD processor, and 16 gb ram, and my FPS on the second worst setting ranges between 60 to 30 in normal play, but the game's actual material in peak settings is on par with something that's like, ten years old?), it crashes pretty much once per hour. Sometimes those crashes are severe enough to require a hard restart of my PC -- I checked on the forums and this isn't an isolated incident, either, and has happened to people on a wide range of systems - on high end to low end computers. Combined with the massive grind wall to get access to the content with even a shred of depth, and this game was a huge let down for me. I *really* wanted to like this game, but *DO NOT* let the trailer fool you. It is *not* what it's advertised as.

Ascent - The Space Game Review Overview First of all, this game is not suited for every single age group. If you were born in the 80's or 90's, they you should probably like it due to the nostalgia level graphics of a AAA game made in that time period. Early Access Review
								Do I like this game, yes. Why? Read all the positive reviews, the points are thorough.  Ones I didn't see listed are it's procedurally generated. Complex trading system but not overly complicated.  I like to play the market, so with hyperdrives (being able to jump to systems as long as you have hydrogen, which is fuel for hyperdrive) and you can find lucrative trade routes.Do I recommend this game, yes.  Why? The community is full of helpful people.  This is probably the most helpful and friendly community that I've seen in a very long time.  With so many toxic communities / forums out there, this one is a breathe of fresh air.  People actually work together.Would I buy it again, yes.  Why?  While I want to get the name out there and support the dev (Jam) for such a great vision in what I'm looking for, some people are on a budget and I do believe the web client you can get completely free and play in a browser.  You can use up to class 5 ship modules on a free account (non-premium, which is the cheapest I've seen in any game, it's like 3 bucks a month or something) and you can only build in the inner planets which number to about 8 I think ( the warp gate linked planets, outer systems is a reference to everything outside the inner systems)Major things to point out that sold me on this game not listed above:-The dev Jam interacts with the community on a daily basis, he listens, looks at the bug reports, hotfixes these bugs he's made aware of on a daily basis as he can get to them, and he keeps the community updated.  This guy is very transparent about what he's doing / trying to do.-Sinstrite made a youtube series on this game which also helped sell me.  His youtube channel is here: https://www.youtube.com/user/Sinstrite and I recommend starting with episode one.  I personally watched and enjoyed them all before buying.  If you're  only going to watch one vid, I recommend the develepor (dev) interview.-When you buy this game off Steam (currently 17ish bucks) and first load into the game, you will show up as newuser#.  You will need to register to setup your in-game handle.  You can find this at the top in game, under options > register.  Now if you buy through Steam, you have 3 months premium when you want to use it.  I recommend learning the game / get as far as you feel is right for you before activating premium as this extends your time in a way and is simply not needed.  Now if you get to the bigger ships and want to get into mining mainly then I recommend the best mining laser you can get as the class modules are basically multipliers.  Just ask questions / watch vids / use the wiki (in-game help " H " links to the wiki) the wiki is located here: http://wiki.thespacegame.com/mediawiki/index.php/Main_Page-The game forums are here: http://forum.thespacegame.com/-Once you decide to claim your Steam 3 months premium I recommend, setting your Steam account to public (just change it back after registering), Having the Steam overlay on (It's on by default unless you tell it to be off by default).-I go by the $1 per hour price when gauging if a game is worth it or not, entertainment wise.  I payed 17 bucks since it's on  sale on Steam, and I have 40 hours at the time of this writing.  So according to my gorilla math, it's well worth it.-I highly recommend using the wiki and asking questions in game.  The community is fantastic and helpful, this alone makes the game worth it imo.-There's many other things not listed such as programmable command in the ship computer that let you do many, many things, the most common is ejecting unwanted cargo.  You can bind all these commands using alias.  Think Valve games where you can bind keys using alias's.  It's very helpful and complex, again all this stuff is on the wiki.  There's way too many to list.-This is obvious but needs to be said.  This game is Early Access.  There will be bugs.  This is run by a one man dev team and he busts his backside trying to further this game.  There's new stuff added / fixed daily and the beauty of it the server usualy isn't taken down to do these, it's just there, you download  the updates.  You should know it's  EA by the huge blue text and Early Access sub game list it's under and that means it's not release, so before you go buying into what the four negative reviews compared to the 40ish+ positive ones, look at what they are saying and think about what EA is before taken them to heart.-The mining system is the most fun in any space game I've played.  You have to interact / pay attention while mining, It's skill based meaning you have to get between a certain temperature range which determines how much ore you get, and it you do too little or too much temperature then you get nothing (too little and you just have to do it again, too much heat and the asteroid is vaporized).  Asteroids can grow in size / yield the longer they aren't mined.  This system encourages exploration in finding lucrative asteroid fields once you get a hyperdrive.  It's a very unique and welcomed way to mine.All in all this game is fun so far and I'm enjoying the ride / community.  As always I recommend watching youtube /  twitch vids before  making a decision, and hopefully you'll come to the same conclusion I did and pick up the game.  See you in game!

Early Access Review
								Ascent - The Space Game is a PvE "sandbox" MMOG which features you in a spaceship so you can mine or fight your way to economic prosperity and the ability to colonize planets anywhere in the galaxy. For the TL;DR set, some brief highlights, both positive and negative. I've deliberately not attached these labels to these highlights so -you- can decide for yourself what they are. The galaxy is huge!  It is repeatedly asserted that it would take years to explore the entire galaxy. If you discover one of the billions of star systems out there, it gets named after you. Note that anyone can do this in a matter of days; I saw a fairly new player discover a star system just yesterday.  Deep space exploration requires a hyperdrive matched to your ship and fuel; you can skim gas giants to get this fuel.  The colonization mechanics look extremely interesting. You really do have to take scientific measurments on a planet and determine if it's worth colonizing. Once you colonize, you actually have to do some engineering (making breathable atmosphere, dealing with gravity and air pressure, etc).  Before colonization happens, you almost certainly will build settlments (planetary mining and food production) and a starbase (research, certain factories, ship construction, ship modules). These can be done much faster and from day one. They still require resources to build, just not as much.  It's somewhat repetitive (grindy) to make money. Once you "tier up" and build some settlements, it does get faster. Planetary colonization should be considered a top tier financial effort.  Blueprint research is "gated" and takes quite a long time, forcing purchases from older players to get started (unless you want to wait over two months).  For those that like community, you can decide to build a jump gate in your sector. Building jump gates requires a massive resource effort from multiple players to complete.  This game is developed by -one- guy. While this is impressive, it does mean updates may not be as fast as most gamers demand them. Overall I recommend this game because I like it.  However, this game may not be for everyone, and I encourage you to read on past the TL;DR point to understand my perspective better.TL:DR pointI've been playing a short time (46 hours over two weeks) and wanted to start a review before the repetitive nature of what I'm doing casts the game in a more negative light than I'd like.  So this is more of a stream of consciousness description for those that want more information or to see where I'm coming from. Note well that I'm not a veteran player, and that my perspective will more closely match a new player's perspective...I feel this kind of perspective is more valuable because a veteran has usually overlooked things that are annoyances and/or game-breakers to most people. These issues obviously don't game break for the vets since....they are still playingMy draw to this game is this: I've learned there is a set of what look like awesome colonization mechanics that appear to make it worth grinding to get to. In studying these mechanics, it seems there's a lot of interesting engineering to be done just to find a spot to colonizxe, let alone manage and maintain your colonies. It seems you have to build and manage environmental domes (unless the atmosphere is perfect) and supply them with the atmospheric gases you need to maintain a habitable environment for your colonists. You have to do this before you can get to any of the good stuff (e.g. growing food, mining resources) that a colony will help you with. The caveat here is that I can't do any of this neat gameplay yet. I need to make at least a billion or two before I can afford it, plus I need to research a few key factory blueprints and get more settlements up producing goods. This brings me to my pet peeve of this game...Research.Researching anything: 24 hours. Increasing the level of something: level * 24 hours. ("Class" is a synonym for "level" in this game). Class 12 gear is what you'll need for the top tier ship that you can get. It will take you over two months (78 days) just to research ONE key ship module to that level. Examples of key modules: weapons, hyperdrives, mining beams, and ram scoops. This means I'm mostly forced to buy these modules from players if I want to make faster progress. (You can argue that I could spend the better part of the year just logging in long enough to cycle my research to the next class. That's ludicrious to me, but technically true.)This is not game breaking for me, but see above...I have a draw that I want to explore. There have been a couple of discussions in chat about this issue where frustration was expressed and I'm sure new players will find this frustrating. Be ye warned if you want to play. I still think it's worth it, but that's me. If you are going to research, you'll want to build your starbase quickly. This is going to require cash for blueprints (available via the contracts board) and resources (available from space stations and players). If you want a steady stream of resources (income), you can start building settlements. Settlements, set up correctly, allow one a certain amount of resource income per day. Both settlements and starbases take a bit of work to setup; it's going to take many trips for you if your ship's cargo hold is small. I waited until I had a big enough ship. Yes, there's repetitive content. Making money for me was initially about buying low to fill my cargo holds and selling high between space stations, easily reached by the autopilot menu.  Once I had enough money, I could buy the next tier of ship which holds more cargo. This allowed me to make money even faster. If you are new, please discover the "stock market search" in the map screen; this will allow you to find places to buy trade goods even cheaper. At some point, for me this was when I was flying a class 6 ship, trading becomes less lucrative than mining asteroids. I was able to get a relatively inexpensive class 5 mining beam and suddenly I was swimming in lucrative resources. I was able to use contracts (available at space stations) and the previously mentioned stock market search to turn the resources into credits.  So...at the moment, when I want more cash, I go farm asteroids. Repeatedly. I do vary where I do this, and because my cargo hold isn't uber huge (I'm in a hammer atm) I do have to break and go drop off/sell my cargo. It's not bad at all for me, and I -am- what people call "ADD" so I do need lots of stimulus to not be bored.  But this is me. So, if you like space games, resource factories, economics, and science...this game is definately for you. I may revisit this review after I've been playing a lot longer.

								I've played this game 4 days now.  And the clock says I've got 48 hrs in.  That's with logging in to play, exiting when I am not playing.  Needless to say, this game has grabbed my interest in a way that other games haven't.  The last game I got this interested in was WoW back in 2005.This game is a space exploration, mining, building, crafting, MMORPG.  There is a Galactic Market (auction) that you can put your crafted or used items on.  There are contracts from NPCs you can run to get credits.  There is limited PVE but no PVP (yet).It has a rapidly expanding community, as it was *just* released on Steam EA a few days ago.  There are a few die hard Kickstarter supporters that are firmly entrenched and know everything, a few middle of the roaders, and a bunch of noobs fast gaining experience.  The community is typically friendly and helpful.  They never seem to tire of answering the same questions over and over from the newest noobies.  They are charitable with advice, and occasionally ship upgrades.  The game developer actually logs in and chats with players fairly often, answering questions and generally being friendly.  One concern I always have coming into a game where some have been playing it for a while is that they tend to stake out their claims to the best of whatever resources you can find.  They have the best gear, and I hate playing catch up ball.  However, this game has 270 billion (with a b) explorable star systems.  Everyone can name a system after themselves, and colonize a planet.  And everyone else can come visit.  And as to gearing up, it happens quickly.  You progress from a tiny ship to a humongous ship in your first few days.  There are more things to aspire to (ie bigger ships yet, starbases, colonies, star systems named after you), so there is always room to grow.The pros of this game are it is fun, has a great community, a lot to do, and loads of potential.  The cons are a somewhat clunky interface (sorry Jam!), and that it is still a work in progress.  But it is a fun, playable, very social work in progress.This game is well worth getting.  If you have read this far, you are wasting time; go get it and get exploring!  I would gladly recommend this game.

My fellow players have devised new plans and projects, all of which enhance my game.It’s just pure fun.

Early Access Review
								Here's a little video introduction I made, showing what the gameplay is like:


YouTube™ Video: Ascent - The Space Game First Look 01 

			Views: 1,845		

			Ascent - The Space Game just released on Steam Early Access today. It's described as a PVE sandbox space MMO with base building, trading, etc.		

I'm really digging it so far. The tutorial is easy to follow, the controls are smooth, and navigating around is pain free. You can either free fly or click on destinations to autopilot, and when you do that it's FAST. I mean, you're at your destination almost instantly. I've never played a space game before where getting around was so quick and painless.As you move from station to station you can accept contracts, which change at random intervals. There's also a story mission that starts during the tutorial and continues, leading you "breadcrumb" style through the different aspects of the game... trading, navigating, accepting contracts, and so on, until eventually you're led to start exploring.The main draw, for me at least, is the PVE focus. PVP sandbox space games are a dime a dozen, but the developers of Ascent - The Space Game have decided to do something different to really stand out from the crowd, and I couldn't be happier.Land you can develop SimCity style, placing buildings and such? It's in there, yep. Way cool. This game reminds me of Yankee Trader / Trade Wars in that way, how you can own and manage property. Blueprints for different buildings and technologies are expensive at first, but Rome wasn't built in a day was it?[Update 3/1/2015]I've put some more time into it and I've noticed a few areas that could use some improvement. First off, sometimes it's not real obvious what to do, or how to do what you want to do. For example, I was looking at the shipyard and found an ultra light fighter and it was cheap, so I bought it. I flew around but I couldn't shoot anything. I thought maybe it didn't come with guns, but I couldn't figure out how to look. I ran through the tutorial again just to make sure, and when the drone came out I was able to shoot it (took FOREVER) but before and after that my guns didn't do anything. I had to ask in chat what was up and people said they only work if you're aiming at an enemy NPC or an asteroid. Oh, that would have been nice to know, the UI should tell you why things aren't working.I got a quest to deliver 10 miner robots to 3 different places, but I couldn't figure out where to get them. I had to ask around and someone said "contract board". Oh, so you have to get these from the contract board, but it's random whether you'll find them available there. Nothing in the contract description says this, and if the NPC who gave me the contract to deliver these robots told me, I'd forgotten.I sold my starter ship because I didn't think I'd need it anymore. I put it up on the global market, and then it was gone. I changed my mind and wanted to cancel the sale but nothing I could find in the UI or any of the menus showed how to do that. I googled it and searched the forums but no answer. Again I had to ask in chat, and they said "Just buy it back from the GM." I found another starter ship just like the one I'd just sold for even less and bought it, but huh, that was awkward.What I'm saying is, the UI could use some improvement. More information. Maybe the tutorial could also explain things a bit better. Also, I asked and was told that there's not really much in the way of co-op in the game. There aren't incentives for co-op or any way to form wings or squadrons. There are a few shared community projects like gates and such, but in terms of forming a group to go raid a base or provide escort, that's not really a thing. More social / co-op features would be good. Maybe random events or group missions? Or pirates building bases or sending out invasion fleets, making people have to band together to drive them back? I don't know, I think things like that are probably being planned.Being a sandbox game it's easy to get lost or reach a point where you're not sure what to do next. That's my problem with most sandbox games and this one is no exception. I'd like to be a combat pilot and take contracts for bounty missions but it looks like you pretty much have to do mining and trading before you can get a ship good enough for combat. So yes, technically you're free to do whatever you want, but you still have to jump through certain hoops to get there. Still though, the game is way more accessible than the X series or Evochron Mercenary.

												I would not recommend to purchase this game. The Bad:- The controls, camera movement, and quasi-realistic-but-totally-not ship movement are a huge step backward compared to many other space games. For instance, even though it is easy to implement in Unity, there isn't a mouse look mode option. Instead one has to hold the right mouse button (only in FPS view) to use the mouse look, which has a massive dead zone that can't be changed and causes UI elements to be activated  and control to be lost when the mouse moves over them. Inexcusable, even for an "indie game" - I didn't have any problem following the mouse look tutorials when I was working with Unity.- The land based graphics are straight out of 1991, but it looks nice in space. - The human characters are honestly laughable.  They would be fine for an open source hobby game, but not in a game people are expected to pay for.- Streaming assets rather than simply allowing all the assets to be downloaded ahead of time. I don't care that Guild Wars 2 takes 30GB of my hard drive space - at least it doesn't completely freeze because it has to download new assets when I turn the camera. - Memory leaks that cause my computer to lock up, while the game thrashes the living daylights out my drives. Only way to stop it is to turn off the PC. - The quest system is incomplete and does not have proper tracking or logs, as we have grown to expect with games since the days of MUDs.  - System messages and quest text are also not logged, so if you miss some information it's just gone. - MANY people have complained (in the short time I played) about the salvaging mission being nearly impossible to complete, due to the poorly developed UI. The developer doesn't see this as his problem, rather as the player's lack of skill. It is 100% a game design issue (lay folk didn't have any issues with SWG Jump to Lightspeed quests, in my several years of experience helping people in that game... because the UI was made by professionals). The Good: - It's a PvE game and you can't even accidentally die or lose your ship. - The mining and commodity trading mini games are well done. - If you enjoy playing "Space Trucker", then this game is worth looking at. You can make lots of credits just auto piloting from place to place, buying low and selling high as you go.- It's not utterly awful, but it's not good either. It would make a fine open source game that people could dabble in and submit patches for, but it isn't something that I would feel comfortable charging money for had it been one of the games I made; it shouldn't be a commercial product. Lesson learned: Don't spend money on "indie games". The hype is real...WARNING: Steam will not give you refund if you play long than 2 hours. It took me several hours of reading and tinkering just to figure out what to do...

												This game is a particularly successful way of making a space game fun to play at least for a few months off gaming.The universe is full of delightful things to discover and to enjoy.  While there is a lot to learn, it is easily taken on board in incremental steps of discovery.  The Ascent Wiki is fantastic, as are the You Tube demonstrations. There is not shortage of tutoarial materials that you can access that will explain everything to you.  As well as this, there is a very helpful community online that are happy to take the time to answer questions as they are asked.There is little in the way of major conflict, (unless you choose to go looking for it), as conflict is currently optional at this time. There is no Galactic War going on and I am thankful for this fact.  Having grown tired after years of eternal shoot them ups, I really enjoy this as a hobby style adventure of wonder and discovery.  The online players are working in a collaborative effort to unfold "Space, the Final Frontier" as you read this review.I read that the developer intends to ultimately make a PVP area for those that are busting to have a fight with their space ships and there is already at this time a PVE area that is optional to go into.The graphics are reasonable. (There have been major upgrades ongoing and getting better all the time). The personal development is great.  The trading system works OK.  There are tons of things to do that are interesting: such as finding new places to fly and trade, discovering new worlds that get named after you, building bigger and better ships, building and developing colonies / making your own starbases / your own mining operations / researching new technology / building stargates / running for political office ingame / building the community / interacting with some very nice people / learning new strategy to build up your own wealth and prestige and lots of discovery.  There is lots of intricasy in this game.  Enough to keep you interested and occupied for a very long time.  There are lots of incredibly interesting details to learn in producing space stations / colony settlements / automted factories and NPC run trading runs.The game is very well priced for what you get.  For those that choose to stay with the game over the long term in the community and continue to grow your ownership there is an "option" to pay an ongoing fee of just three dollars a month.  There are no other costs to players.  You can play for free as long as you want to, but have some limitations on on how big you can become.  I think this is fair enough as the developer is endeavouring to keep the cost to a bare minimum.  I can't see any similar level of game that keeps the price at this level.The game, (as with most others), has a few minor bugs and glitches from time to time, but none of these I have found to be a game-breaking event.  The game saves itself automatically, all the time, as you play.  If anything goes wrong, a simple restart of the game has always gotten rid of the problem and put  me right back where I was with the problem solved. On the negative side I must say that the game has not got long-term playing possibilities with ongoing fun.  I found that after 6 months of play, I had exhausted the game and that it became tedious for me.
