Early Access Review
								Ascent the Space Game is a wonderful find, I've been playing for months and am not tired of it yet in the least.The concept behind the game is that you begin piloting a basic ship, and make your way into the universe.  Tutorial missions will guide you at first, and it's definitely worth it to complete these as they will give you access to a plot of land to place some mines on, a Star Base in which you can construct components necessary to colonize worlds, build ships, etc.The game universe consists of a small core of 9 NPC run inner planets.  Each planet is in a system, and you travel between them using gates.Outside of that is when the game really begins... as there are millions of unexplored star systems out there.  Players can explore, colonize worlds and build colonies producing minerals, food, alcohol, etc.  Construction of Gates between these systems are large cooperative projects, but there are many already in place and more planned.Which brings me to the community.  The player community in Ascent is fantastic.  I've rarely felt at home in a game like I do in Ascent.  Certainly one of the big selling points to me.  Another positive for me is that PVP is not really an issue.  Roughly a quarter of the Galaxy is designated for the "Red Zone", which is the only place PvP can take place (it wasn't in effect at the time of this review).  The game is still in development... changes come often.  New ships, new asteroids to mine, new things to build with new minerals, smuggling is soon to be added, and PvE combat will be a priority after that.For the price, I don't think you can go wrong.  Yes there is a small (and I do mean small) monthly fee for advanced features, but the game comes with three months for free which you can activate when you want.So if the thought of getting into a ship and exploring, mining, colonizing untamed worlds, etc... while interacting with an outstanding gaming community, appeals to you... then you just can't go wrong with Ascent the Space Game.

												First thing off the mark, this is a game with great potential.It is a great game to play, though it has a few limitations that reduce the length of time I will be involved in it.The background of the game is that a spacefaring human civilisation has collapsed to the point where only a few systems clustered together and linked by stargates survive.Starting in a small ship, you are now equipped to begin your career as a Civilian Pilot and help to being prosperity to the Inner Systems, and to expand into the greater unknown to colonise and restore humanity to its former position as a sprawling mass of connected systems.The way to wealth and advancement in the early part of the game is to follow the starter missions which allow you to begin to develop your own plot of land as an Inner Settlement, then expand to your own Inner Starbase.  During the starter narrative and missions, you learn to trade, mine and skim Gas Giants for resources – just to name a few.It is engaging and there is a lot to discover.As you progress and, when you activate the Premium subscription you get with the game purchase (3 months of each type of Premium access), you are able to firstly create and develop Settlements on 8 of the Inner Nine (I9) systems, and greatly expand your Inner Starbase.During this time, your Trading and asteroid Mining skills will increase, as can you Skimming skills if you continue to farm Gas Giants for resources.Outside of the I9 are the Outer Systems.Everything here is developed by the players – well, the Jam-1 system is a little different.So, in the systems that are not part of the starting area, every Stargate and every colony and every Starbase has been built by the player community.  I say player community as the Stargates themselves require so much in the way of resources, it requires a number of players co-operating to complete these projects.At all times, you are able to pilot your ship to these Outer Systems to buy from players at their Starbases and colonies, and haul resources back to the I9 to increase profit.That’s the basics and I have mostly enjoyed my experience.  There are a few things that imo are missing, could be better, or could just go…One of my big questions rattling around in my head has been, if humans got this far into the galaxy, even after a collapse, there should be something left.  But there isn’t.  I don’t get that.  As a player explores new star systems with the intent to colonise and therefore open up new areas, surely there would at least be a remnant of the former civilisation.  As you can EVA on planets, I think it would be great to explore ruins of previous colonies.  Hey, there may even be some active NPC colonies out there???Research is a bit, well, meh.  You do have to research new buildings for colonies and Starbases but, after that, it is really only improving on current technology.  I would like to see something better implemented here and, if the game incorporated “lost colonies” it would be really cool if you could find “scraps” of past knowledge that might open up new research horizons.The Political System is a bit raw, and really may not be necessary.  It is really only a system by which to name Planets and Star Systems, and these can change again if a new player is elected to a position of power.  This system has caused some schisms to form and can easily be used as a rather nasty piece pf metagame PVP.  When the Dev had to get involved with a particular dispute on the Forums, he mentioned the Constitutional Rights of the Senators (who can name Star Systems and approve Stargates), but there is no Constitution that I could find…so maybe if there was one, or if System names could only be changed by some sort of consensus, it may avoid the complications of the past.One thing that I really like about this game is the player community.  They are, in the main, helpful and encouraging every step of the way.  Freely giving advice and helping when you’re stuck or unsure, the community makes this game that much more enjoyable.  There are a couple of nasties, but their impact is easily avoided.This is a great game and should be experienced to its full.  I only hope that new directions are implemented so that someone like me can be engaged in other areas as well.

								This is the second game I randomly found on Steam that I've never heard about but is actually fantastic. A True sandbox space (I don't even know how to classify the type of game this is because it feels like we can do anything we want... explore, trade, colonize uncharted planets, improve yourship for combat, etc).  My ship's on board computer has a commandline that allows us to set parameters (quite frankly this was totally unexpected for me, and it adds to the cool factor for me).  There is trade, there is massive exploration opportunities, probably more starsystems than will ever possibly be explored even if this game is around for 20 years.  100s of billiions of stars out there, and we can set up a colony and our own space station eventually.  I'm impressed.  This game appears to have all the features I've always wanted in a space game, and I was shocked at how easy it is to get the hang of.  Although I heard from others using the interstellar communications that the further along we are in the game the more complex it gets.  So I asked them that even if it gets complex can I just still choose to explore, and be mellow.  They said yes this is a sandbox.  They said we could just do the tutorial and take it as slow as we want.  Also it was a nice suprise that ships do not expend energy unless you use hyperdrive to travel to stars without a jump gate.  I also couldn't wreck my ship by crashing into the space station (which was nice since I didn't realize all I had to do was use autopilot to dock my ship).  In any case this is totally up my alley since I don't like micromanaging fuel while still learning a game.  We can keep flying from station to sation, mine, land on planets explore without fear of crashing and blowing up, or running out of fuel until we are ready to go out and take on more deadly stuff.  I don't know folks but this game seems like it is like a real universe.  I read all that stuff on the website about the graphics needing to be better and stuff, but I'm impressed at how immersive this game is and the graphics aren't an issue with me at all.  It also said they were working on improving combat (I honestly haven't tried combat yet, but the list of controlls seem simple enough).  This is still just early access so I totally don't expect this to be feature complete, but my goodness I'm glad I got this game!  I definitely recommend, and I'm not some long term fan boy that is biased about this game.  I really think this is a good find.

												I've had to re-evaluate my review over the last few days.  I've steadily been getting more and more addicted.  Yes, this game has PLENTY of bugs.  Yes, there are things in it not feature complete coming out of early access.  Yes, it is VERY rough around the edges graphically and UI wise.  But it is still attempting something that no other space game has done to date, and with only 1 guy developing it.  So I must preface my main points with this: If you can't handle bugs that cause the game to crash, delete your colony buildings, or cause your fps to drop below 20 due to memory leaks, DO NOT play this.  You will rage quit.I'm still learning the intricacies of this game.  But it's fairly massive in scope.  You will spend many hours learning how to build colonies and work on your personal starbase.  If you follow the tutorial you should be fine.  The game needs alot of work even coming out of early access.  You will get glitchy graphics here and there.  Pirate AI vessel's will usually glitch out and constantly ram your ship, making it easy to dispatch them because they just keep moving forward in front of you and not shooting their weapons.  So yeah, shooting them is really easy when they're a foot in front of your nose.This game was made to build colonies and starbases with.  It has a HUGE universe.  Something like 250 billion planets.  Each new system you warp to is procedurally generated.   You can land on all the planets in the game.  Something that Elite Dangerous doesn't have yet and wont have for awhile.  So keep in mind what I said.  This game was made to build colonies on planets.  The rest of the game isn't fully fleshed out yet.  If you want to make money, buy a bigger ship, strip it, and just mine asteroids all day or collect gas from outer bases, then sell.  Combat will get you some decent money as well because the ships are glitched right now and pose very little threat.This game is a carebear game.  You can't lose your ship or die, ever.  If your health gets too low, the ship computer auto warps you out of the combat area.  You don't even fight other enemy ships unless you're in ONE particular system.  So taking all that into consideration, you can tell the developer wanted this to be a colony crafting space game with some minor combat content.  You have various skills that improve with use.  I love this skill system and wish more MMO's used it.  The better the skill is, the more money you'll make while doing that activity.  Unfortunatly combat doesn't have any skills as far as I can tell.  Only gas harvesting, mining, trading and colony maintenance.  The colony system is very in depth.  Crafting buildings on planets comes with alot of maintenance on your part.  The people will need food stores and other various activities to maintain morale.  On the flip side, the colonies will produce resources for you.  You can land on your colonies and the colonies of others, get out of your ship and do things like take soil samples, visit another players nightclub or bar and recruit NPC's to fly your ships for you, etc.  Colony expansion is the reason to play Ascent.  It IS the endgame.  Ascent is primarily all about colony construction and building outer starbases throughout the universe to expand the dwindling human race.  Outer planet colonization is much differant than inner 9 colony maintenance.  Think of the inner 9 planets as the starting worlds all noobs visit to learn the game.  Outer planets require environmental domes to sustain life on them, unless they have oxygen and nitrogen in the atmosphere, otherwise, they are like any earth like planet.All the jump gates in game were created by other players.  So if you want to explore, you need a hyperdrive.  So the player base is pretty nice from what I've seen and help players get hyperdrives for cheap.  THere are players here that have played Ascent for over 2 years now.  So the jump gates are pretty common in the core worlds.   The dev is planning on implementing pvp in a certain zone and that's all.   This game, again, is primarily to avoid gankers.  So if you're coming here from Eve Online and want to screw with people, you won't get that chance here. This game has a few broken features, like combat.  So the only other thing to do to make money is trade carbon from one system to another.  Making money is soooooo easy once you get to a class 8 or 9 ship. You will be making upwards of 92 mil/hr just trading from one system to another. It's ridiculously easy. I'm in a class 13 ship at the time of this review, and am making 3 billion credits per hour hauling carbon.  The game turns into a time waster grinding money for hours to get a bigger ship to make even more money.  Like I said above however, this game is all about rebuilding humanity one colony at a time.  So the players base is supposed to work together to build bases and colonies on all the planets and build star gates so travel is easier. That, is end game.  My review/impression video:

								Was going to write a Review on the game at 100 hours game play, Reached that within the week and still had not scratched the surface of this amazing game so decided to try it at 500 hours, oops got lost in the game. For a handful of people making this game it truely is amazing. There is plenty to do within the game and you dont have to sit on a set path to enjoy it. Dont feel like hauling goods?, go kill some npc ships. Dont want to explore?, build up your own base, Dont want to salvage ship parts off wrecks?, go mine asteroids that move and turn around your space-ship. Speaking of ships the different ships and carrying capacity is mind blowing for an alpha game, zip around in a 6 direction mini-frigate or carry tens of thousands of tonnes of materials in a freighter, trading with friends or npc's around the galaxy.Like shiney objects? there are about 270Billion of them! all ready to be explored. Early Access Review
								I wish I could get a refund for this awful game. I lost patience with it after about 2 hours of play. It does nothing that I tell it to do, for example: I agree to a contract where I have to deliver 10 mining robots to 3 seperate colonies. So I dock with a space station and buy 10 mining robots .... so where are they? It tells me i'm carrying NO cargo! I repeat again and again, but to no avail. Next I accidently unfit the warp drive from my ship, I try to refit it and ..... nothing! Now I'm stranded and can't go anywhere or do anything. So I give up and try to exit the game .... nothing to click on to exit, I have to open task manager to stop the game running. I know it's early access, but this game is an unplayable waste of money!!
